awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Empowering Microgrids with Smart Grid Attributes: Developments in U.S. and Africa (To be held January 28-31,2019 in Abuja, Nigeria)
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to organize the first international workshop devoted to evaluating options for empowering microgrid with smart grid attributes with a focus on developments in the United States and Africa.  The project is jointly funded by the Division of Electrical, Communications, and Cyber Systems and the Office of International Science and Engineering. The workshop will involve energy experts, researchers, and university scholars/students as well as policy makers and market players as participants and invited speakers at plenary and panel sessions. It will result in new understanding of renewable energy resource applications and microgrid development in U.S. and Africa under different environment and uncertainties in climate change and growing demand for electricity. Further, it will add to the knowledge base for new technologies for optimization and control of energy use to reduce cost as well as minimize greenhouse gases; increase the performance of renewable energy sources in development of smart microgrid systems; and social, regulatory and policy issues as they affect design and deployment of microgrid in different African countries and the United States. It will promote research, education activities and training of students from U.S. and Africa to accommodate the challenges of development of microgrid and smart grid technologies, and joint publication between U.S. and African participants in refereed journals and conference proceedings.

Understanding of recent developments in deployment of microgrid and smart grid both in the U.S and Africa will lead to a sustainable future energy delivery in the two continents. The workshop will expose the U.S. participants to the developmental work of the European and Asian microgrid developers in Africa, which will enhance the collaborative work between the U.S. and African researchers. In addition, it will supplement other efforts being made by U.S. and other international agencies to improve electricity access in Sub-Saharan Africa, especially with focus on increasing entrepreneurship and investment into renewable energy deployment in the U.S. and Sub-Saharan Africa.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project addresses the various technologies for supplying the grid with effective power delivery under different energy resources.

The intellectual merit is utilization of different renewable energies to build a micro/smart grid to serve the underserved and unserved.

Presentations on papers utilizing advanced modelling techniques to account for randomness of renewable energy resources were done. Use of data analytic concepts and its applications in Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology and Machine Learning(ML) was applied in microgrid functions such as load forecast, Renewable Energy prediction and its impact on smart grid design.

Microgrid function and applications in improving grid reliability was address by several presenters.Understanding of technical and social implications of shifting from central energy supply to distributed.Study of the impact of microgrid design to understand reliability, stability, sustainability, resilience, affordability and customer centric.

Development of emerging technologies such as AI, IoT, Machine Learning, cyber security and applications towards improving reliability and security of the system under attack.

A blueprint for the development of Africa-USA Energy Research Center was achieved at the conference.Opportunity of the local universities to get funding from NERC and TETFund to get funding for collaboration with experts in the US.

The conference had a workshop to disscuss the opportunities and challenges related to the new electricity Act in Nigeria. The act is to allow generation, transmission and distribution on state level as it is in the US. Thus, conference participants will have the opportunity to explore more US-Africa colaboration in the future to address identified challenges.

The need of allignment of regualation and polices to achieve the goal of resiliency, reliability, sustainability and customer centricity.  

The workshop has contributed in capacity development in areas of smart grid, gain an understanding in application of AI for power grid. This conference also poses new opportunities for researchers from the US and Africa to applying for funding in areas on interest.

As part of broader impact, the conference has promoted collaboration between Industry, academicians, regulators and government.The work done at the workshop has opened opportunities to test emerging technologies. The conference has foster continued collaboration by establishing platforms to facilitate knowledge exchange. It has also opened up opportunities for students and faculty exchange.
